Generally, an instance of your test class represents the test method 
that you wish to run:  An instance is a test "is a" method.  The 
JUnit 3 TestCase constructor takes a String parameter -- the /name/ 
of the method to run.

Since an instance of a JUnit 3 TestCase child represents 
a 'java.lang.reflect.Method' to run, and takes a String parameter, 
so it can look up that Method, why isn't the constructor parameter a 
Method, rather than a String?  In Java, would it make more sense to 
construct a TestCase (child) with a Method parameter, rather than a 
String name that represents the Method?

For method parameters:
On the Method class, the 'invoke' method takes two parameters:  
The 'Object instance' (which would be 'this' in the TestCase 
example) and the 'Object[] argumentList' array of method parameters.

So, in the JUnit 3 environment, the easiest way to pass parameters 
to TestCase methods would be to have 'Method' and 'Object[] 
argumentList' parameters on the constructor, and to use these when 
invoking the method.

Same goes for JUnit 4; but I assume you'd need a wrapper class to 
hold the Method and argument list data for the test method 
invocation.  (Maybe a Decorator?)
